sentences.text: General Rating Principles

rhetClass.text: General Rating Principles

sentences.text: Disability ratings are determined by applying the criteria set forth in the VA Schedule for Rating Disabilities (Rating Schedule) and are intended to represent the average impairment of earning capacity resulting from disability.

rhetClass.text: Disability ratings are determined by applying the criteria set forth in the VA Schedule for Rating Disabilities (Rating Schedule) and are intended to represent the average impairment of earning capacity resulting from disability.

sentences.text: Disabilities must be reviewed in relation to their history.

rhetClass.text: Disabilities must be reviewed in relation to their history.

sentences.text: Where there is a question as to which of two evaluations apply, the Board assigns the higher of the two where the disability picture more nearly approximates the criteria for the next higher rating.

rhetClass.text: Where there is a question as to which of two evaluations apply, the Board assigns the higher of the two where the disability picture more nearly approximates the criteria for the next higher rating.

sentences.text: See 38 U.S.C. Â§ 1155; 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 4.1, 4.7, 4.10; Schafrath v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 589 (1991).

rhetClass.text: See 38 U.S.C. Â§ 1155; 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 4.1, 4.7, 4.10; Schafrath v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 589 (1991).

sentences.text: A Veteran may experience multiple distinct degrees of disability that might result in different levels of compensation from the time the increased rating claim was filed until a final decision is made.

rhetClass.text: A Veteran may experience multiple distinct degrees of disability that might result in different levels of compensation from the time the increased rating claim was filed until a final decision is made.

sentences.text: Accordingly, separate ratings may be assigned for separate periods of time based on the facts found, which is a practice known as "staged" ratings.

rhetClass.text: Accordingly, separate ratings may be assigned for separate periods of time based on the facts found, which is a practice known as "staged" ratings.

sentences.text: Fenderson v. West, 12 Vet. App. 119 (1999); Hart v. Mansfield, 21 Vet. App. 505 (2007).

rhetClass.text: Fenderson v. West, 12 Vet. App. 119 (1999); Hart v. Mansfield, 21 Vet. App. 505 (2007).

sentences.text: Where there is a question as to which of two evaluations shall be applied, the higher evaluation will be assigned if the disability picture more nearly approximates the criteria required for that rating.

rhetClass.text: Where there is a question as to which of two evaluations shall be applied, the higher evaluation will be assigned if the disability picture more nearly approximates the criteria required for that rating.

sentences.text: Otherwise, the lower rating will be assigned.

rhetClass.text: Otherwise, the lower rating will be assigned.

sentences.text: It is the defined and consistently applied policy of the Department of Veterans Affairs to administer the law under a broad interpretation, consistent, however, with the facts shown in every case.

rhetClass.text: It is the defined and consistently applied policy of the Department of Veterans Affairs to administer the law under a broad interpretation, consistent, however, with the facts shown in every case.

sentences.text: When after careful consideration of all procurable and assembled data, a reasonable doubt arises regarding the degree of disability such doubt will be resolved in favor of the claimant.

rhetClass.text: When after careful consideration of all procurable and assembled data, a reasonable doubt arises regarding the degree of disability such doubt will be resolved in favor of the claimant.

sentences.text: In Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49, 53 (1990), the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans' Claims stated that "a veteran need only demonstrate that there is an 'approximate balance of positive and negative evidence' in order to prevail."

rhetClass.text: In Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49, 53 (1990), the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans' Claims stated that "a veteran need only demonstrate that there is an 'approximate balance of positive and negative evidence' in order to prevail."

sentences.text: To deny a claim on its merits, the preponderance of the evidence must be against the claim.

rhetClass.text: To deny a claim on its merits, the preponderance of the evidence must be against the claim.

sentences.text: See Alemany v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 518, 519 (1996) (citing Gilbert, 1 Vet. App. at 54).

rhetClass.text: See Alemany v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 518, 519 (1996) (citing Gilbert, 1 Vet. App. at 54).

sentences.text: Entitlement for an initial disability rating in excess of 70 percent for PTSD

rhetClass.text: Entitlement for an initial disability rating in excess of 70 percent for PTSD

sentences.text: Rating Principles: PTSD

rhetClass.text: Rating Principles: PTSD

sentences.text: PTSD is rated under the schedule of ratings for mental disorders, 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.130, DC 9411.

rhetClass.text: PTSD is rated under the schedule of ratings for mental disorders, 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.130, DC 9411.

sentences.text: The rating criteria are as follows:

rhetClass.text: The rating criteria are as follows:

sentences.text: A 70 percent rating is warranted for occupational and social impairment, with deficiencies in most areas, such as work, school, family relations, judgment, thinking, or mood, due to such symptoms as: suicidal ideation; obsessional rituals that interfere with routine activities; speech intermittently illogical, obscure, or irrelevant; near-continuous panic or depression affecting the ability to function independently, appropriately and effectively; impaired impulse control (such as unprovoked irritability with periods of violence); spatial disorientation; neglect of personal appearance and hygiene; difficulty in adapting to stressful circumstances (including work or a work-like setting); inability to establish and maintain effective relationships.

rhetClass.text: A 70 percent rating is warranted for occupational and social impairment, with deficiencies in most areas, such as work, school, family relations, judgment, thinking, or mood, due to such symptoms as: suicidal ideation; obsessional rituals that interfere with routine activities; speech intermittently illogical, obscure, or irrelevant; near-continuous panic or depression affecting the ability to function independently, appropriately and effectively; impaired impulse control (such as unprovoked irritability with periods of violence); spatial disorientation; neglect of personal appearance and hygiene; difficulty in adapting to stressful circumstances (including work or a work-like setting); inability to establish and maintain effective relationships.

sentences.text: A 100 percent rating is warranted for total occupational and social impairment, due to such symptoms as: gross impairment in thought processes or communication; persistent delusions or hallucinations; grossly inappropriate behavior; persistent danger of hurting self or others; intermittent inability to perform activities of daily living (including maintenance of minimal personal hygiene); disorientation to time or place; memory loss for names of close relatives, own occupation, or own name.

rhetClass.text: A 100 percent rating is warranted for total occupational and social impairment, due to such symptoms as: gross impairment in thought processes or communication; persistent delusions or hallucinations; grossly inappropriate behavior; persistent danger of hurting self or others; intermittent inability to perform activities of daily living (including maintenance of minimal personal hygiene); disorientation to time or place; memory loss for names of close relatives, own occupation, or own name.

sentences.text: The psychiatric symptoms listed in the above rating criteria are not exclusive, but are examples of typical symptoms for the listed percentage ratings.

rhetClass.text: The psychiatric symptoms listed in the above rating criteria are not exclusive, but are examples of typical symptoms for the listed percentage ratings.

sentences.text: Mauerhan v. Principi, 16 Vet. App. 436 (2002).

rhetClass.text: Mauerhan v. Principi, 16 Vet. App. 436 (2002).

sentences.text: Although the Veteran's symptomatology is the primary consideration, the Veteran's level of impairment must be in "most areas" applicable to the relevant percentage rating criteria.

rhetClass.text: Although the Veteran's symptomatology is the primary consideration, the Veteran's level of impairment must be in "most areas" applicable to the relevant percentage rating criteria.

sentences.text: Vazquez-Claudio v. Shinseki, 713 F.3d 112 (Fed. Cir. 2013).

rhetClass.text: Vazquez-Claudio v. Shinseki, 713 F.3d 112 (Fed. Cir. 2013).

sentences.text: In evaluating psychiatric disorders, VA has adopted and employs the nomenclature in the rating schedule based upon the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders of the American Psychiatric Association (DSM).

rhetClass.text: In evaluating psychiatric disorders, VA has adopted and employs the nomenclature in the rating schedule based upon the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders of the American Psychiatric Association (DSM).

sentences.text: As such, the diagnosis of a mental disorder should conform to the DSM.

rhetClass.text: As such, the diagnosis of a mental disorder should conform to the DSM.

sentences.text: Effective August 4, 2014, VA amended the portion of its Rating Schedule dealing with mental disorders and its adjudication regulations that define the term "psychosis" to remove outdated references to the Fourth Edition of the DSM (DSM-IV) and replace them with references to the recently updated Fifth Edition (DSM-5).

rhetClass.text: Effective August 4, 2014, VA amended the portion of its Rating Schedule dealing with mental disorders and its adjudication regulations that define the term "psychosis" to remove outdated references to the Fourth Edition of the DSM (DSM-IV) and replace them with references to the recently updated Fifth Edition (DSM-5).

sentences.text: See 79 Fed. Reg. 149, 45094 (August 4, 2014).

rhetClass.text: See 79 Fed. Reg. 149, 45094 (August 4, 2014).

sentences.text: The provisions of the interim final rule apply to all applications for benefits that are received by VA or that were pending before the AOJ on or after August 4, 2014.

rhetClass.text: The provisions of the interim final rule apply to all applications for benefits that are received by VA or that were pending before the AOJ on or after August 4, 2014.

sentences.text: VA adopted as final, without change, the interim final rule and clarified that the provisions of this interim final rule do not apply to claims that have been certified for appeal to the Board or are pending before the Board on or before August 4, 2014, even if such claims are subsequently remanded to the AOJ.

rhetClass.text: VA adopted as final, without change, the interim final rule and clarified that the provisions of this interim final rule do not apply to claims that have been certified for appeal to the Board or are pending before the Board on or before August 4, 2014, even if such claims are subsequently remanded to the AOJ.

sentences.text: Because the AOJ certified the Veteran's appeal to the Board in March 2014, this claim is governed by the DSM-IV.

rhetClass.text: Because the AOJ certified the Veteran's appeal to the Board in March 2014, this claim is governed by the DSM-IV.

sentences.text: Under the DSM-IV, diagnoses many times will include an Axis V diagnosis, or a Global Assessment of Functioning (GAF) score.

rhetClass.text: Under the DSM-IV, diagnoses many times will include an Axis V diagnosis, or a Global Assessment of Functioning (GAF) score.

sentences.text: The GAF is a scale reflecting the psychological, social, and occupational functioning on a hypothetical continuum of mental health illness.

rhetClass.text: The GAF is a scale reflecting the psychological, social, and occupational functioning on a hypothetical continuum of mental health illness.

sentences.text: See Carpenter v. Brown, 8 Vet. App. 240, 242 (1995).

rhetClass.text: See Carpenter v. Brown, 8 Vet. App. 240, 242 (1995).

sentences.text: According to the DSM-IV, in relevant part, a GAF score between 31 and 40 is indicative of some impairment in reality testing or communication (e.g., speech is at times illogical, obscure, or irrelevant) or major impairment in several areas, such as work or school, family relations, judgment, thinking, or mood (e.g., depressed adult avoids friends, neglects family, and is unable to work).

rhetClass.text: According to the DSM-IV, in relevant part, a GAF score between 31 and 40 is indicative of some impairment in reality testing or communication (e.g., speech is at times illogical, obscure, or irrelevant) or major impairment in several areas, such as work or school, family relations, judgment, thinking, or mood (e.g., depressed adult avoids friends, neglects family, and is unable to work).

sentences.text: A GAF score between 41 and 50 is indicative of serious symptoms (e.g., suicidal ideation, severe obsessional rituals, frequent shoplifting) or any serious impairment in social, occupational, or school functioning (e.g., no friends, unable to keep a job).

rhetClass.text: A GAF score between 41 and 50 is indicative of serious symptoms (e.g., suicidal ideation, severe obsessional rituals, frequent shoplifting) or any serious impairment in social, occupational, or school functioning (e.g., no friends, unable to keep a job).

sentences.text: GAF scores ranging from 51 to 60 indicate moderate symptoms (e.g., flat affect and circumstantial speech, occasional panic attacks) or moderate difficulty in social, occupational, or school functioning (e.g., few friends, conflicts with peers or coworkers).

rhetClass.text: GAF scores ranging from 51 to 60 indicate moderate symptoms (e.g., flat affect and circumstantial speech, occasional panic attacks) or moderate difficulty in social, occupational, or school functioning (e.g., few friends, conflicts with peers or coworkers).

sentences.text: GAF scores ranging from 61 to 70 indicate some mild symptoms (e.g., depressed mood and mild insomnia) or some difficulty in social, occupational, or school functioning (e.g., occasional truancy, or theft within the household), but generally functioning pretty well, has some meaningful interpersonal relationships.

rhetClass.text: GAF scores ranging from 61 to 70 indicate some mild symptoms (e.g., depressed mood and mild insomnia) or some difficulty in social, occupational, or school functioning (e.g., occasional truancy, or theft within the household), but generally functioning pretty well, has some meaningful interpersonal relationships.

rhetClass.text: Schedular disability ratings are assigned for the spine from 100 percent to 10 percent according to the formulas as follows:

sentences.text: Under the General Formula, a 20 percent rating contemplates forward flexion of the thoracolumbar spine greater than 30 degrees but not greater than 60 degrees; or, forward flexion of the cervical spine greater than 15 degrees but not greater than 30 degrees; or, the combined range of motion of the thoracolumbar spine not greater than 120 degrees; or, the combined range of motion of the cervical spine not greater than 170 degrees; or, muscle spasm or guarding severe enough to result in an abnormal gait or abnormal spinal contour such as scoliosis, reversed lordosis, or abnormal kyphosis.

rhetClass.text: Under the General Formula, a 20 percent rating contemplates forward flexion of the thoracolumbar spine greater than 30 degrees but not greater than 60 degrees; or, forward flexion of the cervical spine greater than 15 degrees but not greater than 30 degrees; or, the combined range of motion of the thoracolumbar spine not greater than 120 degrees; or, the combined range of motion of the cervical spine not greater than 170 degrees; or, muscle spasm or guarding severe enough to result in an abnormal gait or abnormal spinal contour such as scoliosis, reversed lordosis, or abnormal kyphosis.

sentences.text: Alternatively, under the IVDS Formula, a 20 percent rating contemplates incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 2 weeks but less than 4 weeks during the past 12 months.

rhetClass.text: Alternatively, under the IVDS Formula, a 20 percent rating contemplates incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 2 weeks but less than 4 weeks during the past 12 months.

sentences.text: Under the General Formula, a 40 percent rating contemplates unfavorable ankylosis of the entire cervical spine; or, forward flexion of the thoracolumbar spine 30 degrees or less; or, favorable ankylosis of the entire thoracolumbar spine.

rhetClass.text: Under the General Formula, a 40 percent rating contemplates unfavorable ankylosis of the entire cervical spine; or, forward flexion of the thoracolumbar spine 30 degrees or less; or, favorable ankylosis of the entire thoracolumbar spine.

sentences.text: Alternatively, under the IVDS Formula, a 40 percent rating contemplates incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 4 weeks but less than 6 weeks during the past 12 months.

rhetClass.text: Alternatively, under the IVDS Formula, a 40 percent rating contemplates incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 4 weeks but less than 6 weeks during the past 12 months.

sentences.text: Under the General Formula, a 50 percent rating contemplates unfavorable ankylosis of the entire thoracolumbar spine.

rhetClass.text: Under the General Formula, a 50 percent rating contemplates unfavorable ankylosis of the entire thoracolumbar spine.

sentences.text: There is no equivalent rating under the IVDS Formula.

rhetClass.text: There is no equivalent rating under the IVDS Formula.

sentences.text: Under the IVDS Formula, a 60 percent rating contemplates incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 6 weeks during the past 12 months.

rhetClass.text: Under the IVDS Formula, a 60 percent rating contemplates incapacitating episodes having a total duration of at least 6 weeks during the past 12 months.

sentences.text: There is no equivalent rating under the General Formula.

rhetClass.text: There is no equivalent rating under the General Formula.

sentences.text: Under the General Formula, a 100 percent rating contemplates unfavorable ankylosis of the entire spine.

rhetClass.text: Under the General Formula, a 100 percent rating contemplates unfavorable ankylosis of the entire spine.

sentences.text: There is no equivalent rating under the IVDS Formula.

rhetClass.text: There is no equivalent rating under the IVDS Formula.

sentences.text: In evaluating disabilities of the musculoskeletal system, it is necessary to consider, along with the schedular criteria, functional loss due to flare-ups of pain, fatigability, incoordination, pain on movement, and weakness.

rhetClass.text: In evaluating disabilities of the musculoskeletal system, it is necessary to consider, along with the schedular criteria, functional loss due to flare-ups of pain, fatigability, incoordination, pain on movement, and weakness.

sentences.text: DeLuca v. Brown, 8 Vet. App. 202 (1995).

rhetClass.text: DeLuca v. Brown, 8 Vet. App. 202 (1995).

sentences.text: Although pain may cause functional loss, pain itself does not constitute functional loss.

rhetClass.text: Although pain may cause functional loss, pain itself does not constitute functional loss.

sentences.text: Rather, pain must affect some aspect of "the normal working movements of the body," such as "excursion, strength, speed, coordination, and endurance," in order to constitute functional loss.

sentences.text: CUE is a very specific and rare kind of "error."

rhetClass.text: CUE is a very specific and rare kind of "error."

sentences.text: It is the kind of error, of fact or of law, that when called to the attention of later reviewers compels the conclusion, to which reasonable minds could not differ, that the result would have been manifestly different but for the error.

rhetClass.text: It is the kind of error, of fact or of law, that when called to the attention of later reviewers compels the conclusion, to which reasonable minds could not differ, that the result would have been manifestly different but for the error.

sentences.text: Simply to claim CUE on the basis that previous adjudications had improperly weighed and evaluated the evidence can never rise to the stringent definition of CUE.

rhetClass.text: Simply to claim CUE on the basis that previous adjudications had improperly weighed and evaluated the evidence can never rise to the stringent definition of CUE.

sentences.text: Similarly, neither can broad-brush allegations of "failure to follow the regulations" or "failure to give due process," or any other general, nonspecific claim of "error."

rhetClass.text: Similarly, neither can broad-brush allegations of "failure to follow the regulations" or "failure to give due process," or any other general, nonspecific claim of "error."

sentences.text: Fugo v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 40, 43-44 (1993).

rhetClass.text: Fugo v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 40, 43-44 (1993).

sentences.text: In addition, failure to address a specific regulatory provision involves harmless error unless the outcome would have been manifestly different.

rhetClass.text: In addition, failure to address a specific regulatory provision involves harmless error unless the outcome would have been manifestly different.

sentences.text: Fugo, 6 Vet. App. at 44.

rhetClass.text: Fugo, 6 Vet. App. at 44.

sentences.text: The Court has established a three-pronged test, each of which must be met before CUE is established: either (1) the correct facts, as they were known at the time, were not before the adjudicator (i.e., more than a simple disagreement as to how the facts were weighed or evaluated) or the statutory or regulatory provisions extant at the time were incorrectly applied, (2) the error must be "undebatable" and of the sort "which had it not been made, would have manifestly changed the outcome at the time it was made," and (3) a determination that there was CUE must be based on the record and law that existed at the time of the prior adjudication in question.

rhetClass.text: The Court has established a three-pronged test, each of which must be met before CUE is established: either (1) the correct facts, as they were known at the time, were not before the adjudicator (i.e., more than a simple disagreement as to how the facts were weighed or evaluated) or the statutory or regulatory provisions extant at the time were incorrectly applied, (2) the error must be "undebatable" and of the sort "which had it not been made, would have manifestly changed the outcome at the time it was made," and (3) a determination that there was CUE must be based on the record and law that existed at the time of the prior adjudication in question.

sentences.text: Damrel v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 242, 245 (1994).

rhetClass.text: Damrel v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 242, 245 (1994).

sentences.text: In order to be CUE, the error must be of a type that is outcome determinative.

rhetClass.text: In order to be CUE, the error must be of a type that is outcome determinative.

sentences.text: Glover v. West, 185 F.3d 1328 (Fed. Cir. 1999).

rhetClass.text: Glover v. West, 185 F.3d 1328 (Fed. Cir. 1999).
